text: Have you ever seen Law and Order or CSI?
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Well, if you have, you know how those shows start.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: They always start with a crime.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Someone's running in Central Park, they come across a body, they call the police, the police are there, and then you're hooked, you're engaged, and you have to know what happened.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Then, only then, do they play the theme song, the dun, dun, dun, dun, and you see the credits.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: You might be wondering, what does this have to do with presentation skills?
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Well, just like you want to start off a show and hook the audience, you want to do the same in a presentation.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And we know this in theory.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: But I'll tell you, about 9 out of 10 speakers I see start with their version of the theme song.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: It goes something like this.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Hi, my name's Anne.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: I'm so excited to be here.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Thank you so much for coming.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: In a minute, I'm going to tell you a story.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And on and on and on.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And the speaker can be one or two minutes in, and they haven't said anything interesting.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Guess what?
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Now your audience is on their phone.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: We can do better.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: My name is Anne Ricketts.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: I'm the founder of Lighthouse Communications.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And for a living, I help people deliver more effective presentations.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: I strongly believe that introduction is the most crucial piece to your presentation.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And in this video, I'm going to share with you a four-step formula for killer introduction.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And if you follow this, not only will your audience be leaning in, wanting to hear more, but you will be bursting at the seams with confidence from giving such an amazing introduction.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: You ready for the formula?
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Step one is your hook.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: A story, an analogy, a metaphor, a shocking statistic, a question, or a combination of those things.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Something interesting and vivid right away to pull them in.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Step two is the transition to your topic.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Bridge the gap between that hook and what you're gonna talk about today.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: You can say something like,
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: You might be wondering what CSI has to do with presentations.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: I tell that story because this story illustrates.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Step three is your self-introduction and a preview of your talk.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: If you don't know the audience yet, you can briefly introduce yourself.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Just give them the most interesting things from your background that directly relate to your topic.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And remember, you can establish credibility throughout your talk, so you don't have to give them a full bio.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: and then go ahead and preview what are the goals of your talk, what will you be covering.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Step four is the benefit for your audience.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Tell the audience what they will gain from listening to your talk.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Don't assume that they already know.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: You should be specific.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Now that you know the four steps for giving a killer introduction, let's break it down and let's look at the introduction to this video.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Have you ever seen Law and Order or CSI?
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Well, if you have, you know how the show starts.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: they always start with a crime.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Someone's running, and so that was my hook.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: I asked the audience a question and then painted a picture of a common experience of watching these crime shows.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: You might be wondering, what does this have to do with presentation skills?
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Well, just like you want to start off a show and hook the audience, you want to do the same in a presentation.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: That was my transition to the topic.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: I bridged the gap between my hook and what I'm going to cover in the video.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: My name is Anne Ricketts.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: I'm the founder of Lighthouse Communications.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And for a living, I helped... That was my self-introduction and preview.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: I briefly introduced myself and established some credibility on the topic.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And then I told the audience what we're going to cover in the video.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And if you follow this, not only will your audience be leaning in, wanting to hear more, but you will be bursting... Finally, that was the benefit.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: I told the audience specifically what they will gain from watching the video.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Now you know the four steps for giving a killer introduction.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Try it out and let us know how it goes.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Write a comment on Facebook or on our YouTube channel, and be sure to subscribe to the Lighthouse Communications YouTube channel.
